column1: //A contract address to a new upgraded contract if any
/* Burn PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL and CANNOT_UNWRAP fuses for ROOT_NODE and ETH_NODE */
* @notice Set the metadata service. Only the owner can do this
* @return String uri of the metadata service
function uri(uint256 tokenId) public view override returns (string memory) {
* @notice Set the address of the upgradeContract of the contract. only admin can do this
* @dev The default value of upgradeContract is the 0 address. Use the 0 address at any time
* to make the contract not upgradable.
* @notice Checks if msg.sender is the owner or approved by the owner of a name
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @notice Checks if owner or approved by owner
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @param addr which address to check permissions for
* @return whether or not is owner or approved
* @notice Gets fuse permissions for a specific name
* @dev Fuses are represented by a uint32 where each permission is represented by 1 bit
*      The interface has predefined fuses for all registry permissions, but additional
*      fuses can be added for other use cases
*      Also returns expiry, which is when the fuses are set to expire.
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @return fuses A number that represents the permissions a name has. Returns 0 when expiry < block.timestamp
* @return expiry Unix time of when the name expires and fuses are to expire
* @notice Wraps a .eth domain, creating a new token and sending the original ERC721 token to this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner of the name on the .eth registrar or an authorised caller on the registrar
* @param label label as a string of the .eth domain to wrap
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
// transfer the token from the user to this contract
// transfer the ens record back to the new owner (this contract)
* @dev Registers a new .eth second-level domain and wraps it.
* @param label The label to register (Eg, 'foo' for 'foo.eth').
* @param wrappedOwner The owner of the wrapped name.
* @param duration The duration, in seconds, to register the name for.
* @param resolver The resolver address to set on the ENS registry (optional).
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
* @return registrarExpiry The expiry date of the new name on the .eth registrar, in seconds since the Unix epoch.
* @param tokenId The hash of the label to register (eg, `keccak256('foo')`, for 'foo.eth').
* @param duration The number of seconds to renew the name for.
* @return expires The expiry date of the name on the .eth registrar, in seconds since the Unix epoch.
(address owner, uint32 fuses, uint64 oldExpiry) = getData(
* @notice Wraps a non .eth domain, of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the registry or an authorised caller in the registry
* @param name The name to wrap, in DNS format
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the wrapper or an authorised caller in the wrapper
* @param newRegistrant sets the owner in the .eth registrar to this address
* @param newController sets the owner in the registry to this address
* @notice Unwraps a non .eth domain, of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner in the wrapper or an authorised caller in the wrapper
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the name e.g. vitalik.xyz would be namehash('xyz')
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name, e.g. vitalik.xyz would be keccak256('vitalik')
* @param newController sets the owner in the registry to this address
* @param fuses fuses to burn (cannot burn PARENT_CANOT_CONTROL)
// Only the parent can burn the PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL fuse.
(address owner, uint32 oldFuses, uint64 expiry) = getData(
* @notice Upgrades a .eth wrapped domain by calling the wrapETH2LD function of the upgradeContract
*     and burning the token of this contract
* @dev Can be called by the owner of the name in this contract
* @param label Label as a string of the .eth name to upgrade
* @param wrappedOwner The owner of the wrapped name
* @notice Upgrades a non .eth domain of any kind. Could be a DNSSEC name vitalik.xyz or a subdomain
* @dev Can be called by the owner or an authorised caller
* Requires upgraded Namewrapper to permit old Namewrapper to call `setSubnodeRecord` for all names
* @param parentNode namehash of the parent name
* @param label Label as a string of the name to upgrade
* @param wrappedOwner Owner of the name in this contract
* @param resolver resolver contract for this name
/* @notice Sets fuses of a name that you own the parent of. Can also be called by the owner of a .eth name
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the name e.g. vitalik.xyz would be namehash('xyz')
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name, e.g. vitalik.xyz would be keccak256('vitalik')
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
(address owner, uint32 oldFuses, uint64 oldExpiry) = getData(
// max expiry is set to the expiry on the registrar
// max expiry is set to the expiry of the parent
// if PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL has been burned and fuses have changed
* @notice Sets the subdomain owner in the registry and then wraps the subdomain
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the subdomain
* @param label label of the subdomain as a string
* @param fuses initial fuses for the wrapped subdomain
* @param expiry when the fuses will expire
* @notice Sets the subdomain owner in the registry with records and then wraps the subdomain
* @param parentNode parent namehash of the subdomain
* @param label label of the subdomain as a string
* @param resolver resolver contract in the registry
* @param fuses initial fuses for the wrapped subdomain
* @param expiry expiry date for the domain
* @notice Sets records for the name in the ENS Registry
* @param node namehash of the name to set a record for
* @notice Sets resolver contract in the registry
* @dev Allows an operation only if none of the specified fuses are burned.
* @param node The namehash of the name to check fuses on.
* @param fuseMask A bitmask of fuses that must not be burned.
* @notice Check whether a name can call setSubnodeOwner/setSubnodeRecord
* @dev Checks both canCreateSubdomain and canReplaceSubdomain and whether not they have been burnt
*      and checks whether the owner of the subdomain is 0x0 for creating or already exists for
*      replacing a subdomain. If either conditions are true, then it is possible to call
* @param node namehash of the name to check
* @param labelhash labelhash of the name to check
* @notice Checks all Fuses in the mask are burned for the node
* @param fuseMask the fuses you want to check
* @return Boolean of whether or not all the selected fuses are burned
//check if it's the eth registrar ERC721
// transfer the ens record back to the new owner (this contract)
function _canTransfer(uint32 fuses) internal pure override returns (bool) {
function _addLabel(string memory label, bytes memory name)
// burn and unwrap old token of old owner
emit NameWrapped(node, name, wrappedOwner, fuses, expiry)
// Expiry cannot be more than maximum allowed
// .eth names will check registrar, non .eth check parent
// Expiry cannot be less than old expiry
// Mint a new ERC1155 token with fuses
// Set PARENT_CANNOT_REPLACE to reflect wrapper + registrar control over the 2LD
function _canFusesBeBurned(bytes32 node, uint32 fuses) internal pure {
}",7024.0,963.0,"[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper

Due to re-entrancy possibility in `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` (called from `setSubnodeOwner` and `setSubnodeRecord`), it is possible to do some stuff in onERC1155Received right after transfer but before new owner and new fuses are set. This makes it possible, for example, to unwrap the subdomain, but owner and fuses will still be set even for unwrapped domain, creating fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for domain, which is not owned by NameWrapper.
[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy

By design, the child node's expiry can only be extended up to the parent's current one. Adding these restrictions means that the ENS users only have to look at the name itself's fuses and expiry (without traversing the hierarchy) to understand what guarantees the users have.
When a parent node tries to `setSubnodeOwner / setSubnodeRecord`, the following code is used to guarantee that the new expiry can only be extended up to the current one.
[H-03] `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node
By design, for any subdomain, as long as its `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burnt (and does not expire), its parent should not be able to burn its fuses or change its owner.

However, this contraint can be bypassed by a parent node maliciously unwrapping itself. As long as the hacker becomes the ENS owner of the parent node, he can leverage ENSRegistry::setSubnodeOwner to re-set himself as the ENS owner of the subdomain, and thus re-invoking the function `wrap` can rewrite the fuses and wrapper owner of the given subdoamin.

Current permissioning for the function `wrapETH2LD` allows `msg.senders` who are not owner to call it if they are EITHER approved for all on the ERC721 registrar or approved on the wrapper. Allowing users who are approved for the ERC721 registrar makes sense. By giving them approval, you are giving them approval to do what they wish with the token.
[M-07] If `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry

There is a general incorrect logic of allowing to burn only `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse without burning `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuse. If only `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burnt, then domain can be unwrapped by its owner and then wrapped again, which clears `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse, making it possible for parent to bypass the limitation of parent control before the expiry.",5.0,"pragma solidity ^0.8.4

emit NameWrapped(node, name, wrappedOwner, fuses, expiry)
function _canFusesBeBurned(bytes32 node, uint32 fuses) internal pure {
I’m digging into vulnerabilities in the solidity code, particularly looking at the onlyController and onlyOwner functions, and assessing custom elements like ERC1155Fuse.

I’m examining onERC721Received and _normaliseExpiry(), where _normaliseExpiry() ensures expiry remains non-declining, potentially preventing malicious users from setting excessively high or low expiry values.
I'm assessing _burn, setSubnodeOwner, and setSubnodeRecord, ensuring authorization is robust. Also, a malicious upgradeContract could gain full control over registrar and ens.
I’m concerned about the trust in the owner and upgradeContract, as a compromised owner key could lead to significant security issues. This setup might centralize control and pose significant risk.
I'm looking into how ens and registrar calls might be spoofed or malicious, potentially causing re-entrancy or data corruption. Trust issues are key here.
I’m evaluating renew, upgradeETH2LD, and setChildFuses functions, noting how overwriting expiry, relying on upgradeContract, and controlling subnode fuses can create trust risks.
Confirming the absence of tx.origin, ensuring the use of ENS standard hashing and node calculation, and noting the code's handling of _unwrap and fuse state logic.
I’m examining the registrar and ens methods, OnlyController, and the absence of integer overflow or unswappable fuses, with a focus on max and error handling.

I’m considering the implications of ens.setApprovalForAll() granting upgradeContract broad control over ENS records, suggesting a significant trust risk. Also, OperationProhibited might originate from ERC1155Fuse.

I'm noting that if an ENS node is owned by the contract, _transferAndBurnFuses might allow unintended fuses rewriting, and logic vulnerabilities might emerge from non-critical operationAllowed placements.
I'm thinking through the lack of a reentrancy guard in the code, which could allow upgradeContract to call back into NameWrapper and possibly disrupt the contract's assumptions or state.
I'm examining vulnerabilities: centralization risk due to the onlyOwner mechanism and the absence of reentrancy guards in the contract, which could disrupt state invariants.
I'm thinking through potential vulnerabilities, including reentrancy due to untrusted upgradeContract, unintended fuse logic errors, and the lack of checks when disabling upgradeContract.

I’m considering trust in external ens and registrar calls, potential reentrancy if these contracts are malicious, and the risk from upgradeContract. These factors could significantly impact security.","**Summary of Potential Vulnerabilities and Risks**

The contract’s owner holds significant power, particularly the ability to set or change the `upgradeContract`. Once set, this `upgradeContract` is granted full `setApprovalForAll` permissions on both the `ENS` and the `registrar`. This effectively gives the owner indirect control over all wrapped names and potentially allows them to delegate control to any arbitrary contract. If the owner's key is compromised, the attacker can set a malicious upgrade contract and gain unauthorized control over all wrapped domains.

The contract interacts with external contracts (`ens`, `registrar`, and `upgradeContract`) without implementing any form of reentrancy guard. While the official ENS and BaseRegistrar contracts are generally considered safe, if the `upgradeContract` or any future integrated contract is malicious and can reenter during callbacks, it might exploit the lack of reentrancy protections. This could potentially allow attackers to execute functions multiple times in a single transaction, leading to state inconsistencies or unauthorized operations.
3. **Complex Fuse Logic and Potential Edge Cases**:

The contract introduces complex logic around ""fuses"" that restrict certain operations (e.g., `CANNOT_TRANSFER`, `CANNOT_UNWRAP`, `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL`). Any subtle error in these logic checks could enable an attacker to bypass intended restrictions. For example:
- Improperly combining fuse values might allow restricted operations if a specific edge case is overlooked.

- `_canFusesBeBurned` and `operationAllowed` modifiers are critical choke points. If there's an unexpected interaction or a misapplied fuse mask, it might allow operations that should be permanently disallowed.
The contract trusts `ENS` and `BaseRegistrar` to behave as intended. If these external dependencies deviate from the expected standard or become compromised, it could introduce vulnerabilities:
- If the `registrar` or `ens` contracts are upgraded or replaced (in a system where upgrades are possible), malicious behavior could exploit the NameWrapper’s assumptions.

- The `upgradeContract` is also an external dependency set by the owner. A malicious or bug-ridden upgrade contract can perform unexpected actions, given it will have sweeping approvals and can potentially call back into the `NameWrapper`.
5. **Lack of Explicit Access Control Beyond Owner and Controllers**:

While `onlyOwner` and `onlyController` checks protect some functions, the overall design still relies heavily on the correctness of these roles. A misconfigured controller or an owner account breach places the entire system at risk.

The main concerns revolve around centralization of power in the owner’s hands (especially through setting the `upgradeContract`), the absence of reentrancy guards, and the complexity of the fuse-based permission system. These issues do not necessarily constitute outright vulnerabilities if the contracts and keys are properly managed and trusted. However, from a security standpoint, they represent high-impact risks that should be clearly understood, audited, and mitigated where possible.","---
#### **[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper**

The `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` function, called from `setSubnodeOwner` and `setSubnodeRecord`, is vulnerable to reentrancy attacks. Specifically, during the `onERC1155Received` callback, an attacker can perform actions (e.g., unwrapping a subdomain) before the new owner and fuses are set. This allows the creation of fake ERC1155 NameWrapper tokens for domains not owned by the NameWrapper, leading to inconsistencies and potential exploitation.
Matches with **""No Reentrancy Protection""** in the response list.

**Partially Correct**. The response identifies the lack of reentrancy protection as a general issue but does not explicitly address the specific vulnerability described in the issue. While the response acknowledges the absence of reentrancy guards and the risks of interacting with external contracts, it does not propose concrete mitigation strategies (e.g., implementing `nonReentrant` modifiers or checks-effects-interactions patterns) for the `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` function.
- Explicitly recommend adding reentrancy guards (e.g., `nonReentrant` modifier) to the `NameWrapper._transferAndBurnFuses` function and other vulnerable functions.
- Ensure that state changes (e.g., setting the new owner and fuses) occur before external calls to prevent reentrancy exploits.
- Consider using the checks-effects-interactions pattern to minimize reentrancy risks.
#### **[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy**

The child node's expiry can be extended beyond the parent node's expiry, violating the guarantee policy. This creates a situation where users cannot rely on the expiry and fuses of a child node without traversing the hierarchy, leading to potential confusion and mismanagement of ENS domains.

**Unaddressed**. The response list does not mention this issue or provide any mitigation strategies. This is a critical oversight, as the issue directly impacts the integrity and usability of the ENS hierarchy.
- Introduce a validation mechanism to ensure that a child node's expiry cannot exceed the parent node's expiry.
- Add tests to verify that the expiry constraints are enforced during operations like `setSubnodeOwner` and `setSubnodeRecord`.
- Clearly document the guarantee policy to ensure developers and users understand the constraints.
#### **[H-03] PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node**

The `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is designed to prevent a parent node from controlling a subdomain. However, this restriction can be bypassed if the parent node maliciously unwraps itself. By becoming the ENS owner of the parent node, an attacker can reset the subdomain's owner and fuses, effectively regaining control over the subdomain.
Matches with **""Complex Fuse Logic and Potential Edge Cases""** in the response list.

**Partially Correct**. The response acknowledges the complexity of the fuse logic and the potential for edge cases but does not specifically address the bypass of `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` through malicious unwrapping. The response also does not propose specific solutions to prevent this bypass.
- Implement additional checks to ensure that unwrapping a parent node does not reset the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse for subdomains.
- Consider introducing a mechanism to permanently lock certain fuses, even if the parent node is unwrapped.
- Add tests to cover edge cases involving malicious unwrapping and re-wrapping of parent nodes.

The `wrapETH2LD` function allows `msg.senders` who are not the owner to call it if they are approved for all on the ERC721 registrar or approved on the wrapper. While approval on the ERC721 registrar is reasonable, extending this permission to the wrapper introduces unnecessary risk and overextends the function's permissioning.

**Unaddressed**. The response list does not mention this issue or provide any mitigation strategies. This is a significant oversight, as improper permissioning can lead to unauthorized actions and security vulnerabilities.
- Restrict the `wrapETH2LD` function to only allow calls from the owner or approved addresses on the ERC721 registrar.
- Review and simplify the permissioning logic to minimize the risk of unauthorized access.
- Add tests to ensure that only authorized users can call the `wrapETH2LD` function.
#### **[M-07] If PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry**

The logic allowing the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse to be burned without also burning the `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuse is flawed. This allows the subdomain owner to unwrap and re-wrap the domain, clearing the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse and enabling the parent to regain control before the expiry.
Matches with **""Complex Fuse Logic and Potential Edge Cases""** in the response list.

**Partially Correct**. The response highlights the complexity of the fuse logic but does not specifically address the issue of unwrapping and re-wrapping to bypass the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse. The response also does not propose specific solutions to address this logical flaw.
- Enforce a rule that the `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuse must be burned if the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` fuse is burned.
- Add tests to ensure that unwrapping and re-wrapping cannot be used to bypass fuse restrictions.
- Clearly document the intended behavior of the `PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL` and `CANNOT_UNWRAP` fuses to avoid confusion.
The response highlights the risks of centralization in the owner's ability to set the `upgradeContract`. While this is a valid concern, it is not directly related to the issues in the `issue` report.
The response discusses the risks of trusting external contracts like `ENS` and `BaseRegistrar`. While this is a valid concern, it is not directly related to the issues in the `issue` report.
- **[H-01] It is possible to create fake ERC1155 NameWrapper token for subdomain, which is not owned by NameWrapper**.
- **[H-03] PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL can be bypassed by maliciously unwrapping parent node**.
- **[M-07] If PARENT_CANNOT_CONTROL is set on subdomain, it can be unwrapped then wrapped by its owner and then parent can control it again before the expiry**.
- **[H-02] The expiry of the parent node can be smaller than the one of a child node, violating the guarantee policy**.

}",2905.0,320.0,"[M-04] BytesUtil.compare returns wrong result on some strings longer than 32 characters

Due to incorrect condition in `ByteUtil.compare` function, irrelevant characters are masked out only for strings shorter than 32 characters. However, they must be masked out for strings of all lengths in the last pass of the loop (when remainder of the string is 32 characters or less). This leads to incorrect comparision of strings longer than 32 characters where len or otherlen is smaller than string length (characters beyond provided length are still accounted for in the comparision in this case while they should be ignored).
[M-06] BytesUtils: compare will not revert when the `offset` and `len` exceeds the bytes lengths
Compare will return false answer without reverting when the inputs are not valid.
The function `equals` with offset might return true when equals without offset returns false.",3.0,"pragma solidity ^0.8.4

#### **[M-04] BytesUtil.compare returns wrong result on some strings longer than 32 characters**

The `BytesUtil.compare` function incorrectly handles strings longer than 32 characters. Specifically, irrelevant characters are masked out only for strings shorter than 32 characters. For strings longer than 32 characters, the masking logic fails during the last pass of the loop (when the remainder of the string is 32 characters or less). This results in incorrect comparisons where characters beyond the provided length are still considered, even though they should be ignored.
